clinical_study.brief_title: Revascularization in Nonagenarian Patients With Critical Lower Limb Ischaemia
clinical_study.official_title: Revascularization Results in Nonagenarian Patients With Critical Lower Limb Ischaemia

brief_summary.textblock: The rise in life expectancy implies an increased number of nonagenarian patients who need evaluation for critical lower limb ischaemia (CLI). The study goal is to evaluate whether revascularization techniques in these patients fulfill a set of security and efficacy criteria generated from surgical results in a validated historical cohort.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence at 30 days of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE)
primary_outcome.description: Incidence at 30 days of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE): stroke, myocardial infarction or death by cardiovascular cause, in percentage.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence at 30 days of major adverse limb events (MALE)
primary_outcome.description: Incidence at 30 days of major adverse limb events (MALE): limb acute ischemia or amputation, in percentage.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence at 30 days of limb major amputations (MA)
primary_outcome.description: Incidence at 30 days of limb major amputations (MA), in percentage.

secondary_outcome.description: Percentage of revascularized limb which do no require major amputation at 12 months
Percentage of patients alive at 12 months

arm_group.description: Patients suffering from Critical Limb Ischemia aged 90 year-old or above who undergo limb revascularization by means of open surgery or endovascular revascularization
